snippet.textDisplay:
There's a couple of problems with this report:

1) We're going to need hydrocarbons for fuel for a long time; there's no magic switch that will make renewable energy work in the quantity or locations its needed. Therefore, oil exploration will need to continue until renewable energy technology, specifically energy storage, can meet these demands.

2) "...so that oil can compete with renewables". This narrative is completely false. Green energy companies historically has failed to turn a profit without public subsidies, of which they have recieved in the hundreds of billions. Much more development is required before green energy can compete with oil, not the other way around.

3a) It was nice of VOX to show Google's progress in creating a more sustainable future, but this was super understated. 100% renewable energy use is an enormous amount of energy and an achievement unrivaled in scale by other companies. To act like helping the oil companies become more efficient undoes that progress is really putting a thumb on the scale when measuring this "offense".

3b) It also lends fuel to fire of the opposition; there is a heavy "climate alarmists will never be satisfied by progress" narrative on the right, and this further reinforces that. If achievements are not recognized by major climate change activists, companies will feel less incentive to adopt co2 saving measures.

4) An extension of point 1, oil exploration will need to continue for some time. It can either be done with old, less efficient methods, or streamlined to reduce its overall carbon footprint. What this video basically does is smear Google for making the best out of a bad situation.

5) The effects of CO2 emissions are far overstated. More recent studies show the effects will max out around 2 deg C, and we're already almost to 1.5. HOWEVER, there are far more insulating gases such as SF6, which is used in windmill switchboxes and is a highly potent greenhouse gas. It has a global warming potential (GWP) 23,900 times greater than that of CO2 and an atmospheric life of 3,200 years. That's estimated, but nobody really knows if or when this ridiculously stable gas will break down.

Conclusion: we should be focusing on building up companies and people for doing the right thing and making progress rather than creating hype about what they do wrong. Progress, even when incremental, needs celebrating. We also need to focus on fixing real problems with the best data and make sure our solutions do less harm than good. Thanks for reading.

1) We're going to need hydrocarbons for fuel for a long time; there's no magic switch that will make renewable energy work in the quantity or locations its needed. Therefore, oil exploration will need to continue until renewable energy technology, specifically energy storage, can meet these demands.

2) "...so that oil can compete with renewables". This narrative is completely false. Green energy companies historically has failed to turn a profit without public subsidies, of which they have recieved in the hundreds of billions. Much more development is required before green energy can compete with oil, not the other way around.

3a) It was nice of VOX to show Google's progress in creating a more sustainable future, but this was super understated. 100% renewable energy use is an enormous amount of energy and an achievement unrivaled in scale by other companies. To act like helping the oil companies become more efficient undoes that progress is really putting a thumb on the scale when measuring this "offense".

If achievements are not recognized by major climate change activists, companies will feel less incentive to adopt co2 saving measures.

4) An extension of point 1, oil exploration will need to continue for some time. It can either be done with old, less efficient methods, or streamlined to reduce its overall carbon footprint. What this video basically does is smear Google for making the best out of a bad situation.

5) The effects of CO2 emissions are far overstated. More recent studies show the effects will max out around 2 deg C, and we're already almost to 1.5. HOWEVER, there are far more insulating gases such as SF6, which is used in windmill switchboxes and is a highly potent greenhouse gas. It has a global warming potential (GWP) 23,900 times greater than that of CO2 and an atmospheric life of 3,200 years. That's estimated, but nobody really knows if or when this ridiculously stable gas will break down.

Progress, even when incremental, needs celebrating. We also need to focus on fixing real problems with the best data and make sure our solutions do less harm than good. Thanks for reading.

snippet.textDisplay:
While I appreciate the hypocrisy pointed out by this video, there is also an implicit assumption that if only Google/Amazon/Microsoft were to not sell this technology to the Oil and Gas industry, they would not be able to do anything with AI. In reality, AI technology is widespread, and there would be a host of other companies and people helping AI technology reach the oil & gas research.
This is quite like saying that Intel/AMD should not cell CPUs to O&G, because the CPUs are being used to drill for more oil.
The real solution has to come at the other end of the marketplace, with a carbon tax like the one proposed by CCL.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't know why they painted extracting and processing fossil fuels more efficiently as a bad thing. The more efficient it is, the less waste there is, and the less environmental effect it will have. Also, even if every car and truck switched to an AI electric vehicle tomorrow, and every KW of electricity was not from fossil fuels, we would still need oil and gas for tons applications. Take a look around your house and take note of all everything around you derived from oil and gas. It's not gonna go away. Yes, we can limit the use. We can also eliminate all subsidies for all energy production and exploration, and let there be a free market once again. Thus without any subsidies to any energy production to interfere, if renewables are as efficient and cost effective as fossil fuels, then it would take over the market.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't know why they painted extracting and processing fossil fuels more efficiently as a bad thing. snippet.textDisplay: Although alarming at first, I’m somewhat aligned with this relationship of “tech and big oil”. On one hand, if these tech companies deliver machine learning and make the extraction an easier process, that might incentivize the further consumption of oil a lower price point. On the other hand, if the consumption of oil is, for the most part, going to continue in some way shape or form, might as well improve the effectiveness of locating and efficiency of extracting what “we” were going to be getting anyways.
snippet.textOriginal: Although alarming at first, I’m somewhat aligned with this relationship of “tech and big oil”. I’m glad Google is working on these initiatives and am interested in the real results not a contrivance presented as real evidence between jump cuts.
This is very disappointing, Do better.

snippet.textDisplay: The fact you mispronounced Total's name lessons your my opinion you have property researched this. (its not pronounced toe-till, but Toe-towel, since its French).  I do agree that time and time again people say oil will be phases out in 10 year, and it hasn't been.  I think it is counterintuitive to Vox's argument.  Oil will exist, so Google, Microsoft, and Amazon maximizing energy's efficiency and helping revolutionize it might be a noble cause as compared to evil as Vox has shown....or at the very least something in between.

snippet.textDisplay:
So I have this theory, and it's just a theory, these crude oils being syphoned from the Earth are lubricating the plates. Notice how earthquakes of devastating power are becoming more frequent?
Yeah, just my theory. No research.

Also, fracking has been known to cause sinkhole mile away from the initial sites. Let's put families, business and who knows what others in danger to make oil float to us.... 😒

Many inventors have vanished for making things that don't run or required any crude oils/fossil fuels. It's sad.

snippet.textDisplay: I get that there are ethical implications but what do you expect them to do? Not allow oil companies to use the technology they produce? AI and cloud services are used by whole host of problematic industries, and aren't just being worked on by Google and Amazon. The genie is out of the bottle now, and if Google or Amazon don't take advantage of this demand from these companies than other tech companies will.
